The Presiding Officer (Ken Macintosh):

next item of business is a statement by the

programme for government. The First Minister’s

there should be no interventions or interruptions

14.08.text:
The First Minister (Nicola Sturgeon):
This is a new Parliament, with new powers,

20.80.text:
operating in a new political, economic and
constitutional context. The programme for

26.38.text:
government that we publish today sets out
how we will use those new powers and adapt

31.46.text:

that will be introduced between now and the

36.39.text:

that government is about more than legislation.

42.03.text:
It therefore sets our legislative programme
in the context of our wider ambitions and—crucially—it

48.13.text:
sets out how we will seek to protect Scotland’s
interests, particularly our economic interests,

52.46.text: in the wake of the European Union referendum.

55.39.text:
Most important of all, the programme demonstrates
how we will implement the mandate that the

59.11.text:
people of Scotland gave us in May to drive
sustainable economic growth, reform education

64.85.text:
and create opportunities for all, transform
our public services and empower local communities.

71.25.text:
Four of the bills that we will introduce this
year will make use of new powers that are

76.57.text:
being devolved to this Parliament. The air
passenger duty bill will enable a replacement

81.66.text:

Government’s intention is to halve the overall

87.41.text:

session, to support growth and improve our

that are even more pressing as a result of

99.65.text:

continuing to exercise their highly specialist

111.49.text:

116.09.text:

chamber. Gender balance on public boards is

122.16.text:
an area in which strong progress has already
been made—2015 was the first year in which

127.70.text:
more women than men were appointed to public
boards in Scotland—but that progress must

132.78.text:
be maintained and built on. The bill will
help to ensure that the public sector leads

138.00.text:
by example in delivering true gender equality
in Scotland.

142.52.text:
Finally, and perhaps most important, we will
introduce a social security bill, which will

Scottish social security system, based on

Work has already started in preparation for

the construction of a smaller women’s prison
on the Cornton Vale site. We will also establish

1488.33.text:
community-based custody units for women offenders
to help rehabilitation and reduce reoffending.

1494.56.text:
From next April, the establishment of community
justice Scotland will bring new national leadership

1500.92.text:
to the community justice sector, thereby ensuring
that it delivers better outcomes for communities

1507.84.text:
We will also protect Police Scotland’s revenue
budget in real terms, delivering an extra

1512.87.text:
£100 million over the parliamentary session.
Crime levels in Scotland are already at their

1518.80.text:
lowest for more than 40 years. By investing
in and supporting our police and by working

1524.96.text:
to reduce reoffending, we will aim to ensure
that the level of crime continues to fall.

1531.46.text:
The final issue that I will talk about today
is community empowerment. We gain significant

1537.91.text:
social and economic benefits by giving people
more control over the decisions that affect

1543.68.text:
them. Over the next year, we will continue
to support community land purchases, working

1549.34.text:
towards our target of one million acres of
land in community ownership by 2020. We will

1555.32.text:
also consult on how communities can benefit
from the devolution of the management of Crown

1559.57.text:
Estate assets to Scotland. We will introduce
an islands bill to ensure that our future

1564.77.text:
policies and legislation take account of the
needs of our 93 island communities.

1571.41.text:
We will implement and build on the Land Reform
(Scotland) Act 2016. Secondary legislation

1575.22.text:
to establish a register of controlling interest
in ownership will be introduced over the next

1580.86.text:
year, heralding unprecedented transparency
around land ownership in Scotland. The Scottish

1587.12.text:
land commission will become operational in
April, and it will advise on issues relating

1593.18.text:
to land ownership and provide an expert source
of evidence for future reform.

1599.12.text:
Finally, we will work with local councils
and communities on extending community budgeting

1604.71.text:
and develop new legislation to further decentralise
budgets and powers. We want Scotland to be

1611.93.text:
a country where community ownership is desirable
and viable and where community-led action

1617.14.text:
is celebrated. I believe that this programme
for government will help us to achieve that.

1621.95.text:
I turn briefly to the EU. Sixty-two per cent
of those who voted in Scotland voted to remain

1629.86.text:
in the EU, and that is why I am determined
to pursue all options to protect our place

1635.23.text:
in Europe. As I said at the outset of my statement,
I will update Parliament more fully tomorrow.

1639.98.text:
However, in order to ensure that all options
are open to us, the programme for government

1644.38.text:
makes it clear that we will consult on a draft
referendum bill so that it is ready for immediate

1648.85.text:
introduction if we conclude that independence
is the best or only way to protect Scotland’s

1655.61.text:
I said at the beginning of my statement that
this is a new Parliament, with new powers,

1664.72.text:
operating in a new constitutional context.
We also have a new domestic political context

1671.27.text:
in our national Parliament, with a social
democratic Government in the mainstream of

1675.91.text:
Scottish public opinion confronted by a right-wing
Conservative Opposition. That

1687.57.text:
means a real battle of ideas; a sense of solidarity
versus the ideology of the small state; a

1694.64.text:
Scottish social security system with dignity
at its heart, not crude attacks on the vulnerable;

1699.66.text:
and a commitment to fair work, not a deregulated
race to the bottom.

1704.37.text:
The programme for government demonstrates
how, with an iron focus on the business of

1708.89.text:
government, we will create opportunity for
all. It outlines how we will support economic

1713.35.text:
growth, invest in childcare and schools, improve
public services and empower our local communities.

1719.78.text:
It explains how we will use our substantial
mandate to deliver on our manifesto commitments.

1725.81.text:
The programme for government will help to
create a wealthier and fairer country, and

1731.22.text: I am proud to commend it to Parliament.
